fields.description_en: The Grand Mosque (Masjid al-Haram) is the holiest mosque in Islam, located in the heart of Mecca, in western Saudi Arabia. At its center stands the Kaaba, which, according to Islamic belief, is the first house of worship built for humanity on Earth. This is the most sacred and revered place on Earth for Muslims. The Grand Mosque is the direction Muslims face in prayer (qibla), and it is the destination of the Hajj pilgrimage. It is called the Grand Mosque because fighting within its precincts has been forbidden since the Prophet Muhammad's triumphant entry into Mecca. Muslims believe that a single prayer performed there is equivalent to one hundred thousand prayers elsewhere.

fields.history_en:
The Construction of the Kaaba

The history of the mosque begins with the construction of the Holy Kaaba. It was first built by angels before Adam (peace be upon him), and it was made of red ruby. This structure was then raised to heaven during the Flood. After the Flood, the Prophet Abraham and his son Ishmael (peace be upon them both) rebuilt the Kaaba after God revealed its location to Abraham (peace be upon him). God Almighty says: {And [remember] when We assigned to Abraham the site of the House, [saying], "Do not associate anything with Me and purify My House for those who perform Tawaf and those who stand [in prayer] and those who bow and prostrate [in prayer]."} (26) (Surah Al-Hajj, verse 26).

Thus, God Almighty commanded Abraham (peace be upon him) to build the Sacred House. The Holy Quran mentions the building of the Kaaba by Prophet Abraham and his son Ishmael (peace be upon them both) and the purification of the surrounding area. The angel Gabriel (peace be upon him) brought the Black Stone to Abraham (peace be upon him). Initially, it was not black but rather a brilliant white, as the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) said, â€œThe Black Stone is from Paradise and was whiter than snow until the sins of the polytheists blackened it.â€

It remained as it was until it was rebuilt by the Quraysh during the pre-Islamic era, about thirty years after the Year of the Elephant, following a great fire at the Kaaba. This fire was caused by a Quraysh woman attempting to fumigate the Kaaba, which ignited and weakened the structure. A flood then came and damaged parts of the Kaaba. The Quraysh rebuilt it, and the Prophet Muhammad, who was 35 years old at the time, was present and personally participated in the work alongside his uncles. When the Quraysh wanted to raise the Black Stone to its place during this rebuilding, they argued amongst themselves, to the point of near-war. They eventually agreed that the first man to emerge from their quarter would judge between them. The Messenger of God was the first to emerge, and he ruled that the Black Stone should be placed in a cloth (or covering) and then lifted by the tribal leaders. They lifted it, and then Muhammad, peace be upon him, ascended and placed it in its place with his own blessed hand. It should also be noted that Qusayy ibn Kilab, one of the Prophet Muhammad's ancestors, was the first to roof the Kaaba, using palm wood and palm fronds, before the Quraysh rebuilt it. For the Kaaba, a long time ago.

fields.description_en: The Kaaba is the direction Muslims face in their prayers, and around it they circumambulate during the Hajj pilgrimage. It is also considered the first house built on Earth according to Islamic belief, and the Grand Mosque (Masjid al-Haram) cannot be mentioned without mentioning the Kaaba, as the mosque's history begins with its construction. Muslims believe that the Kaaba was first built by angels before Adam. It is also known as the Sacred House (al-Bayt al-Haram), so named because God has forbidden fighting within its precincts. Muslims consider it the holiest place on Earth.

fields.history_en:
Quraish built the Kaaba before Islam
The Kaaba remained as it was until it was rebuilt by the Quraysh in pre-Islamic times, about thirty years after the Year of the Elephant, when a major fire occurred in the Kaaba, resulting from an attempt by a woman from the Quraysh to fumigate the Kaaba, so the fire caught fire and the building weakened. Then a torrent came that destroyed parts of the Kaaba, so the Quraysh rebuilt it, and they agreed that they would not enter into its construction except good money, so their expenses fell short, so they took out three meters from the side of the stone;Among the features of their construction is that they raised the door from the level of the floor so that whoever wanted to enter the Kaaba, and they closed the back door opposite this door, and they roofed the Kaaba and made it a gutter that pours rainwater into the debris. They raised the building of the Kaaba 8.64 meters after it was 4.32 metres. The Prophet Muhammad attended it, and he was 35 years old at the time. He personally participated with his honorable uncles in the work, and when the Quraysh wanted to build this building, they had to lift the Black Stone to put it in its place.The clans of Quraysh quarreled among themselves, until war almost broke out between them. Then they agreed that the first man to come out of this path would judge between them. The Messenger of God was the first to come out, so he decided among them that they place the Black Stone in a robe (i.e. a covering), and then the tribal leaders would raise it, so they raised it. Then Muhammad rose and put it in his honorable hand in its place, thereby solving the problem that almost caused wars between the Quraysh tribes.We must also point out that Qusayy bin Kilab, one of the ancestors of the Prophet Muhammad, was the first to roof the Kaaba, as he roofed it with duum wood and palm leaves, long before the Quraysh built the Kaaba.

Abdullah bin Al-Zubair building
During the reign of Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr, the Kaaba was rebuilt after it was damaged by the fire that broke out in the Kaaba after it was thrown by a catapult, during the siege of Mecca by Yazid bin Muawiyah in his dispute with Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr. The reason for the siege was that Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr refused to pledge allegiance to Yazid bin Muawiyah and the Zubayrids revolted with him in Medina. So Yazid sent an army to Medina led by Muslim bin Uqba, and entered it and then headed to Mecca, but he died before reaching it, so he was succeeded in commanding the army by Al-Husayn binAl-Numair, who besieged Mecca for a period, and indeed Al-Husayn was able to control Mount Abu Qubais and Mount Qiqaan. Then he began shooting Al-Zubayr and his followers who were holed up inside the mosque with a catapult, and the mosque was hit. Al-Husayn was not satisfied with that, but rather he threw fire at the mosque, causing the Kaaba to burn, and its structure to weaken. However, Al-Husayn returned to the Levant after Yazid died.

After Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr pledged allegiance to the Muslims as Caliph in the year 64 AH, he had two choices before him: either restore the Kaaba or demolish it and then rebuild it. So he decided to demolish the Kaaba and rebuild it on the foundations of the Prophet Abraham, when he had heard from his maternal aunt Aisha, the Mother of the Believers, a hadith in which the Prophet Muhammad said that the Quraysh diminished in building the Kaaba because their wealth fell short of them, and that if the Quraysh had not become new to Islam, he would have rebuilt it and made it have two doors for people to enter through one of them.And they come out the other.Abdullah rebuilt the Kaaba in this way and increased its construction to be on the foundations of the old building during the era of Abraham, and he made it have two doors at ground level.Its height was twenty-seven cubits, and its walls were two cubits wide. It also had two doors (east for entry and west for exit). Ibn al-Zubayr also expanded the Grand Mosque. This expansion was completed in the sixty-fifth year AH, and doubled the area of â€‹â€‹the mosque, reaching an area of â€‹â€‹ten thousand square metres.

fields.description_en: The Grand Mosque is the greatest mosque in Islam and is located in the heart of the city of Mecca, west of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. In the middle of it is the Kaaba, which is the first house placed for people on the face of the earth to worship God in it according to the Islamic faith, and this is the greatest and holiest spot on the face of the earth for Muslims.The Grand Mosque is the qibla for Muslims in their prayers, and to it they make the pilgrimage.It was called the Grand Mosque due to the prohibition of fighting there since the Prophet Muhammad entered Mecca victorious.Muslims believe that praying there is equivalent to one hundred thousand prayers.

fields.history_en:
The construction stage of the Kaaba
The history of the mosque begins with the history of the construction of the Holy Kaaba. It was first built by angels before Adam, peace be upon him, and it was made of ruby red. Then that building was raised to the sky during the days of the flood. After the flood, the Prophet Abraham, along with his son Ishmael, peace be upon them, rebuilt the Kaaba, after God revealed to Abraham, peace be upon him, the location of the House. The Almighty said: â€œAnd when We appointed for Abraham a placeThe House, that you do not associate anything with Me, and purify My House for those who circle around me, and those who stand and those who kneel and prostrate. 26 (2) (Surat Al-Hajj, verse 26).

Thus, God Almighty commanded Abraham, peace be upon him, to build the Sacred House.The Holy Qurâ€™an mentioned the building of the Kaaba by our master Abraham and his son Ishmael, peace be upon them, and the cleansing of the space surrounding it. Gabriel, peace be upon him, came to him (i.e. Abraham, peace be upon him) with the Black Stone, and it was not black at first, but rather it was sparkling white due to the intensity of its whiteness. This is due to the words of the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, â€œThe Black Stone is from Paradise and it was whiter than snow until it was blackened by the sins of the polytheists.â€

It remained as it was until it was rebuilt by the Quraysh in pre-Islamic times, about thirty years after the Year of the Elephant, after a major fire occurred in the Kaaba, resulting from an attempt by a woman from the Quraysh to fumigate the Kaaba. The fire caught fire and the structure weakened. Then a torrent came that destroyed parts of the Kaaba, so the Quraysh rebuilt the Kaaba. The Prophet, who was 35 years old at the time, attended it, and he personally participated with his honorable uncles in the work, and when the Quraysh wanted to remove the Black Stone in this building.To put it in its place, they quarreled among themselves, until war broke out, then they agreed that the first man to come out of this path would judge between them. The Messenger of God was the first to come out, so he decided among them that they place the Black Stone in a robe (i.e., a covering), and then the tribal leaders would raise it, so they raised it. Then Muhammad, peace be upon him, rose and put it in his honorable hand in its place. We must also point out that Qusay ibn Kilab, one of the grandfathers of the Prophet Muhammad, was the first to roof the Kaaba, as he did its roof.With doum wood and palm leaves, long before the Quraysh built the Kaaba.

fields.history_en:
The construction stage of the Kaaba
The history of the mosque begins with the date of the construction of the Holy Kaaba. It was first built by angels before Adam, peace be upon him, and it was made of ruby red. Then that building was raised to the sky during the flood. After the flood, the Prophet Abraham, along with his son Ishmael, peace be upon them both, rebuilt the Kaaba, after God revealed to Abraham, peace be upon him, the location of the House. The Almighty said:
